content:
The "Drug Free Sports Act" defines terms like "Secretary" and "professional sports associations" and mandates mandatory drug testing for athletes. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates professional sports associations to implement drug testing policies for athletes, including random testing at least once a year. The "Drug Free Sports Act" requires professional sports associations to conduct random drug testing on athletes at least once a year, without prior notification. The Secretary will issue a list of substances to be tested for, as determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates random drug testing for athletes without prior notification. The Secretary will provide a list of prohibited substances determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency for testing. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates random drug testing for athletes using prohibited substances determined by the Secretary as performance-enhancing. Tests must be conducted by an independent party, and positive results lead to suspension. Athletes testing positive for prohibited substances face penalties in the professional sports association, including a minimum 2-year suspension or permanent suspension for repeat offenders. Athletes testing positive for prohibited substances in professional sports face penalties, including a minimum 2-year suspension or permanent suspension for repeat offenders. Suspensions also result in a loss of pay and the disclosure of the athlete's name to the public. Athletes who test positive for prohibited substances in professional sports face penalties, including suspension and loss of pay. The name of the athlete with a positive test result will be made public. Athletes have the right to appeal and must do so within 5 days of learning about the positive test. An athlete who tests positive in professional sports has the right to appeal within 5 days. The appeal process includes a prompt hearing and a final adjudication within 30 days. Penalties are stayed pending the appeal. The Secretary has the authority to exempt professional sports associations from regulations if they already have policies for testing athletes for prohibited substances. SEC. 5. NONCOMPLIANCE.

Starting 1 year after final rules are issued, the Secretary can fine professional sports associations not following testing policies. The initial fine is $5,000,000 and can increase by $1,000,000 per day of noncompliance.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must report on the effectiveness of regulations every 2 years to Congress, including compliance by professional sports associations and instances of noncompliance. Additionally, the Comptroller General will conduct a study on college and secondary school testing policies and procedures. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the use of performance-enhancing substances by college and secondary school athletes, examining prohibited substance policies and testing procedures of intercollegiate athletic associations, college and university athletic departments. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the use of performance-enhancing substances by college and secondary school athletes, examining prohibited substance policies and testing procedures of intercollegiate athletic associations, college and university athletic departments, secondary schools, and State and regional interscholastic athletic associations. A report will be transmitted to the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General will assess testing policies for detecting performance-enhancing substances in college and secondary school athletes. A report will be sent to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will assess testing policies for detecting performance-enhancing substances in college and secondary school athletes, with a report to be sent to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment. Recommendations may be made to expand regulations to athletic associations.
